messages.subject: help with tsuba
messages.msgSnippet: Group, I have a tsuba that is perplexing, I am trying to figure out for sure if it is real or modern. It is much better made than most fake tsuba but I
messages.messageBody:
Group,

I have a tsuba that is perplexing, I am trying to figure out for sure if it is "real" or modern. It is much better made than most "fake" tsuba but I can't seem to get out of the back of my mind that it is modern. any and all opinions please. if anyone has seen this tsuba listed for sale on any sites selling modern tsuba please send me a link. I have taken pictures (best effort), the tsuba appears to be shakudo.

http://www.auctionpix.com/dec1/jonemvc-016s.jpg

http://www.auctionpix.com/dec1/jonemvc-019s.jpg

thanks


Mark Jones
nixe@...


----- Original Message -----
From: alchemyst
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Monday, December 01, 2003 7:02 PM
Subject: [nihontostudy] Re: My Mito tsuba followup


Ken -

The styles of Aizu Shoami and Mito are very similar IMHO.
Although I think the better, high end Mito work is a bit
superior. Both schools did a lot of copying of other
schools (Nara especially) work. Both schools produced
tons of shiriimono, but also some nice pieces. I like
the ones you've shown and hope you are able to get them.
IMHO the school doesn't matter as long as you like them.
(Collect what you like, but like what you collect :-)

Rich S
------------------------------------------------------------
Richard Stein, PhD alchemyst@...

The Japanese Sword Index
